curriculum_content.title: Understanding Large Numbers
curriculum_content.description: Learn the fundamentals of reading and writing numbers up to 10 million

content.learning_objective: Understand how large numbers work and why they're important in everyday life
content.introduction: Let's explore how to read and write really big numbers! Numbers can get huge - up to 10 million and beyond. Once you understand the pattern, it becomes much easier.
concepts: Every digit has a place value - units, tens, hundreds, thousands, etc.
Numbers are read from left to right in groups of three digits
Commas help us separate groups of thousands to make reading easier
The position of each digit tells us its value
content.key_example: 234,567 reads as 'two hundred thirty-four thousand, five hundred sixty-seven'
visual_aids: Place value chart showing millions, thousands, and units
Number line with large numbers marked

curriculum_content.title: Working Through Examples Together
curriculum_content.description: Step-by-step practice with reading and writing large numbers

content.introduction: Let's practice reading and writing large numbers together, step by step.

activities.title: Reading 1,234,567
steps: Put together: One million, two hundred thirty-four thousand, five hundred sixty-seven
activities.description: Break large numbers into manageable groups

activities.title: Writing Numbers from Words

activities.description: Convert word form to standard form

interactive_elements.title: Place Value Sorting
interactive_elements.description: Drag digits to correct place value positions

interactive_elements.title: Complete the Number
interactive_elements.description: Fill in missing digits in large numbers

checkpoints.question: In 5,426,789, what does the 4 represent?
checkpoints.explanation: The 4 is in the hundred thousands place

curriculum_content.title: Practice on Your Own
curriculum_content.description: Independent practice problems to build confidence

content.introduction: Now it's your turn! Practice reading and writing large numbers independently.

exercises.title: Word to Number Conversion
exercises.instruction: Write these word numbers as digits
problems: Four million, three hundred thousand, fifty-six
Seven million, eight hundred ninety thousand, one hundred twenty-three

exercises.title: Place Value Questions
problems: What is the value of 7 in 3,724,891?
What digit is in the ten thousands place in 8,639,254?

self_check: Can you read any 7-digit number confidently?
Do you understand what each digit position represents?
Can you write numbers from words without help?
extensions: Find large numbers in newspapers and practice reading them
Look up population numbers of different countries

curriculum_content.title: Show What You Know
curriculum_content.description: Assessment to demonstrate mastery of large numbers

content.introduction: Time to show what you've learned about reading and writing large numbers!

assessment_questions.question: Write 3,456,789 in words
assessment_questions.correct_answer: Three million, four hundred fifty-six thousand, seven hundred eighty-nine

assessment_questions.question: What is the value of the digit 5 in 8,521,347?
assessment_questions.explanation: The 5 is in the hundred thousands place

assessment_questions.question: Write 'Two million, seven hundred thousand, forty-three' in digits

feedback.good: Great work! You understand large numbers well! 👍
feedback.needs_work: Good try! Let's practice a bit more. 💪

curriculum_content.title: The Art of Rounding
curriculum_content.description: Master the skill of rounding numbers to different place values

content.learning_objective: Understand when and how to round numbers for estimation and practical use
content.introduction: Rounding helps us work with simpler numbers. It's like saying 'about' instead of being exact - super useful for quick calculations!
concepts: Look at the digit to the right of your rounding place
If it's 5 or more, round up
If it's less than 5, round down
All digits to the right become zeros
content.key_example: Rounding 3,456 to nearest hundred: Look at 5 (tens place), it's 5 or more, so round up to 3,500

curriculum_content.title: Rounding Step by Step
curriculum_content.description: Practice rounding with guided examples

content.introduction: Let's round numbers together, starting simple and building up!

activities.title: Round to Nearest 1000
activities.description: Apply same rules to larger places

interactive_elements.title: Rounding Explorer
interactive_elements.description: Move the slider to see how numbers round

interactive_elements.title: Round and Sort
interactive_elements.description: Sort numbers by their rounded values

checkpoints.question: Round 6,789 to the nearest hundred
checkpoints.explanation: Look at tens digit (8), which is ≥ 5, so round up

curriculum_content.title: Rounding Challenge
curriculum_content.description: Practice rounding independently

content.introduction: Show your rounding skills! Work through these problems at your own pace.

exercises.title: Round to Nearest 10
exercises.instruction: Round these numbers to the nearest 10

exercises.title: Round to Nearest 100
exercises.instruction: Round these numbers to the nearest 100

self_check: Do you check the correct digit for rounding?
Can you round to any place value?
Do you remember when to round up vs down?
extensions: Create a rounding game with dice
Estimate your weekly spending using rounding
Round sports statistics in the newspaper

curriculum_content.title: Rounding Assessment
curriculum_content.description: Test your rounding skills

content.introduction: Let's check your rounding expertise!

assessment_questions.question: Round 3,456 to the nearest hundred
assessment_questions.explanation: The tens digit is 5, so round up

assessment_questions.question: Round 67,892 to the nearest thousand
assessment_questions.explanation: Hundreds digit is 8 (≥5), so round up

assessment_questions.question: Which number rounds to 500 when rounded to the nearest hundred?

curriculum_content.title: Comparing and Ordering Numbers
curriculum_content.description: Learn to compare numbers and put them in order

content.learning_objective: Master comparison symbols and ordering techniques for any size numbers
content.introduction: Comparing numbers is like being a judge - you decide which is bigger, smaller, or if they're equal!
concepts: < means 'less than' (smaller number first)
> means 'greater than' (bigger number first)
= means 'equal to' (same value)
Compare digits from left to right
content.key_example: 345 < 354 because when we compare left to right, 4 < 5 in the tens place

curriculum_content.title: Compare and Order Together
curriculum_content.description: Practice comparing and ordering with guidance

content.introduction: Let's practice comparing numbers step by step!

activities.title: Comparing Large Numbers
activities.description: Compare digit by digit from left to right

curriculum_content.title: Roman Numerals - Ancient Numbers
curriculum_content.description: Discover the Roman numeral system still used today

content.learning_objective: Read and write Roman numerals up to 1000 (M)
content.introduction: Romans didn't use our number system - they had their own! You still see Roman numerals on clocks, in movie credits, and on important buildings.
concepts: Add symbols when smaller comes after larger: VI = 6
Subtract when smaller comes before larger: IV = 4
Never use more than 3 of the same symbol in a row

curriculum_content.title: Below Zero - Negative Numbers
curriculum_content.description: Explore numbers less than zero

content.learning_objective: Understand and work with negative numbers
content.introduction: What happens when you go below zero? Negative numbers help us describe temperatures below freezing, depths below sea level, and debts!
concepts: Negative numbers have a minus sign (-)
Zero separates positive and negative numbers
The further from zero, the 'more negative'
-5 is less than -2 (think temperature!)

curriculum_content.title: Mental Math Magic
curriculum_content.description: Develop lightning-fast mental calculation skills

content.learning_objective: Master mental strategies for quick addition and subtraction
content.introduction: Your brain is an amazing calculator! Let's unlock mental math strategies that make you faster than a calculator for many problems.
concepts: Break numbers into friendly parts
Use number bonds and facts you know
Compensation: add too much, then adjust
Near doubles: use doubles you know

curriculum_content.title: Column Addition Mastery
curriculum_content.description: Perfect the traditional method for accurate addition

content.learning_objective: Add multi-digit numbers accurately using column method
content.introduction: Column addition is like stacking blocks - line everything up perfectly and build from right to left!
concepts: Align digits by place value
Start from the ones column
Carry when a column totals 10 or more
The carried digit goes to the next column

curriculum_content.title: Fractions - Parts of a Whole
curriculum_content.description: Understanding what fractions are and how they work

content.learning_objective: Understand fractions as parts of a whole or a set
content.introduction: Fractions are everywhere! When you share a pizza, break a chocolate bar, or measure ingredients, you're using fractions.
concepts: Numerator (top) = parts we have
Denominator (bottom) = total equal parts
The line means 'divided by'
Fractions show parts of one whole
content.key_example: 3/4 means 3 parts out of 4 equal parts

curriculum_content.title: Exploring Fractions Together
curriculum_content.description: Hands-on practice with fraction concepts

content.introduction: Let's work with fractions using visual models and real examples!

interactive_elements.title: Match Fractions to Pictures
interactive_elements.description: Connect fraction notation to visual models

checkpoints.question: If a pizza has 8 slices and you eat 3, what fraction did you eat?
checkpoints.explanation: 3 slices eaten out of 8 total slices

curriculum_content.title: Fraction Practice Time
curriculum_content.description: Work independently with fraction problems

content.introduction: Practice identifying, writing, and creating fractions on your own!

exercises.title: Name the Fraction
exercises.instruction: Write the fraction shown in each diagram

exercises.title: Draw Fractions
exercises.instruction: Draw diagrams to show these fractions

exercises.title: Real-World Fractions
problems: 5 red marbles out of 12 total marbles

self_check: Can you identify the numerator and denominator?
Do your drawings show equal parts?
Can you explain what the fraction means?
extensions: Create a fraction scavenger hunt at home

curriculum_content.title: Fraction Fundamentals Check
curriculum_content.description: Assess understanding of basic fractions

content.introduction: Show what you know about fractions!

assessment_questions.question: What fraction of this shape is shaded? [Shows circle with 3 of 4 parts shaded]
assessment_questions.explanation: 3 parts shaded out of 4 total parts = 3/4

assessment_questions.question: In the fraction 5/8, what does the 8 represent?
options: The total number of equal parts
assessment_questions.correct_answer: The total number of equal parts
assessment_questions.explanation: The denominator (bottom number) shows total equal parts

assessment_questions.question: Draw a diagram to show 2/3
assessment_questions.correct_answer: Any shape divided into 3 equal parts with 2 shaded
assessment_questions.explanation: Should show 3 equal parts with exactly 2 shaded

assessment_questions.question: Sarah ate 4 slices of a pizza that had 10 slices. What fraction did she eat?
assessment_questions.explanation: 4 slices eaten out of 10 total slices = 4/10

feedback.excellent: Fantastic fraction work! You really understand parts and wholes! 🍕
feedback.good: Good job with fractions! You're getting the hang of it! 👏
feedback.needs_work: Keep practicing with fractions - you're making progress! 💪

curriculum_content.title: Equivalent Fractions - Same Value, Different Look
curriculum_content.description: Discover how different fractions can represent the same amount

content.introduction: Did you know that 1/2, 2/4, and 3/6 are all the same amount? They're equivalent fractions - different ways to write the same value!
concepts: Equivalent fractions represent the same part of a whole
Multiply or divide both numerator and denominator by the same number
The fraction's value doesn't change
Simplifying means finding the simplest equivalent fraction

curriculum_content.title: Letters and Numbers - Introduction to Algebra
curriculum_content.description: Begin your journey into algebraic thinking

content.learning_objective: Understand how letters can represent unknown numbers
content.introduction: Algebra is like being a detective with numbers! We use letters to stand for numbers we don't know yet, then solve the mystery!
concepts: Letters (like x, y, n) can represent unknown numbers
An expression combines numbers and letters with operations
We can substitute numbers for letters
Algebra helps us solve problems with unknowns

curriculum_content.title: Working with Algebraic Expressions
curriculum_content.description: Practice using letters in mathematical expressions

content.introduction: Let's practice working with algebraic expressions step by step!

activities.title: Substitution Practice

activities.title: Writing Expressions
steps: Choose a letter for 'a number' (use n)

interactive_elements.title: Build Expressions
interactive_elements.description: Drag and drop to create algebraic expressions

curriculum_content.title: 2D Shapes - Properties and Classification
curriculum_content.description: Explore the properties of flat shapes

content.learning_objective: Identify and classify 2D shapes by their properties
content.introduction: Shapes are all around us! Every 2D shape has special properties that make it unique. Let's become shape detectives!
concepts: Triangles have 3 sides and 3 angles
Quadrilaterals have 4 sides and 4 angles
Regular shapes have all sides and angles equal
Circles have no straight sides or corners
content.key_example: A square is a special rectangle where all 4 sides are equal

curriculum_content.title: Shape Investigation Lab
curriculum_content.description: Hands-on exploration of shape properties

content.introduction: Let's investigate shapes like scientists, discovering their properties!

activities.title: Triangle Types
activities.example: Classify triangles by sides and angles
steps: Scalene: No equal sides or angles

activities.title: Quadrilateral Family
steps: Rectangle: Opposite sides equal, 4 right angles
Rhombus: 4 equal sides, opposite angles equal
Parallelogram: Opposite sides parallel and equal

checkpoints.question: What makes a square special compared to other rectangles?
checkpoints.answer: All four sides are equal in length
checkpoints.explanation: A square is a rectangle with the additional property of equal sides

curriculum_content.title: Shape Detective Challenge
curriculum_content.description: Apply shape knowledge independently

content.introduction: Use your shape knowledge to solve these challenges!

exercises.title: Name That Shape
problems: I have 4 equal sides and 4 right angles. What am I?
I have 3 sides, 2 are equal length. What am I?
I have 4 sides, opposite sides are parallel. What am I?
I have no corners and no straight sides. What am I?

exercises.title: Property Match
exercises.instruction: List all properties of these shapes

exercises.title: Real World Shapes
exercises.instruction: Find examples of these shapes in everyday objects

self_check: Can you name all basic 2D shapes?
Do you know the properties of each shape?
Can you spot shapes in the world around you?
extensions: Design a pattern using different shapes
Research shapes in different cultures' art

curriculum_content.description: Test your knowledge of 2D shapes

assessment_questions.explanation: Penta- means five, so pentagon has 5 sides

assessment_questions.explanation: All rectangles have these properties, but only squares have 4 equal sides

assessment_questions.question: Draw and label an isosceles triangle
